Award.AwardTitle: Factionalism, Trade Goods, and the Colonial Process in Peten, Guatemala

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation funding, Dr. Timothy W. Pugh and a team of international scholars will investigate how European trade goods that flowed into the Maya world transformed indigenous political systems before the Spanish conquest by weakening central authority and increasing factionization. This research will involve two seasons of archaeological excavation and laboratory analysis in Petén, Guatemala. Team members will include professors and students from the United States and Guatemala.

Contact and colonialism are often imagined as indigenous vs. settler/colonist relationships, but cultural entanglements are rarely, if ever, so straightforward. Both native and interloper groups can include factions whose varied intentions play critical roles in the power relations that emerge during situations of contact. During such entanglements, factional struggles transcend boundaries, as factions compete with one another while possibly allied with outsiders. Competing factions have varied perspectives and goals in the aftermath of conquest. It is through such divergent objectives that one might gain a glimpse of the agency involved in the colonial process. This project will investigate these complex negotiations of power, as they are manifest in material culture at two sites in Petén, Guatemala: Nixtun-Ch'ich' and Muralla de Leon. The project will pay particular attention to the shifting role of European material culture in the Itza socio-political system from the Contact period (A.D. 1525-1697) through the early Spanish Colonial period (A.D. 1697-1750), and the effect of Spanish conquest and subsequent colonialism upon Maya social organization and political power.

Through the examination of the practices of restriction and redistribution of European items, the work will illuminate something of the value of these objects. The study of restrictions of use and redistribution by Maya elite of iron, glass, and other European objects will reveal how colonial objects can be strategically appropriated and rejected in the course of contact. The project will reveal how contact and conquest transforms internal social relations leading to factionization, the creation of new alliances, and transformation of power networks.

The research will make a number of broader impacts including the training of both U.S. and Guatemalan students. Dr. Pugh has a longstanding relationship with Centro Universitario del Petén (CUDEP) and will support CUDEP students' efforts to complete research practicums and theses at various levels. This particular impact is critical as students from Petén do not have the resources to undertake and complete their research without external collaborations. Graduate students from The Graduate Center of the City University of New York, Southern Illinois University Carbondale, and other universities will also be supported and will conduct advanced research leading to graduate degrees. Qualified undergraduates from Queens College will also have the opportunity to participate in the project and learn about archaeological methods and research design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Factionalism, Trade Goods, and the Colonial Process in Petén, Guatemala documented a Maya group known as the Chak’an Itza from ca. AD 1100-1750 using archaeological methods. This time period covers pre-contact with the Europeans (before 1525), the Contact period before conquest (1525-1697), and post-conquest (after 1697).  The goal was a long term observation of how contact and colonialism impacted Chak’an Itza politics as well as those of the entire region.  The work focused upon the sites of Nixtun-Ch’ich’ and Muralla de Leon in Petén, Guatemala (Figure 1).

The work at Muralla de Leon revealed that it was a fortress built in a strategic location (Figure 2). Our work revealed that historical accounts were inaccurate as it was not occupied by the Chak’an Itza, but was instead occupied by their allies, the Kowoj. The Chak’an Itza had allied with the Kowoj in a failed attempt to overthrow the ruling group, the central Itza. The research revealed that the site’s defensive walls were more substantial than previously thought and that the defenses also included canals. The defensive system likely predated the Kowoj occupation by 1200 years, so the Kowoj occupied a preexisting fortress for defense. Our work also documented a ceremonial group and a number of residential areas within the fortress.

Spanish chronicles suggested that Nixtun-Ch’ich’ (Figure 1) contained substantial Chak’an Itza settlements before the conquest of the area in 1697 and was the site of two colonial missions after the conquest. Our previous work at the site found one of the Spanish missions, San Jerónimo I, and as part of the current project, we analyzed artifacts from these excavations. In addition, we analyzed artifacts from three other previously excavated settlements at Nixtun-Ch’ich’ dated between AD 1100 and 1697. In addition to these analyses, we conducted extensive mapping and excavations at Nixtun-Ch’ich’.

Our survey of the site used a total station to map over 85,000 data points across the project area (Figure 3). An earlier site map had been composed with old methods adapted to less efficient survey instruments. The new data allow one to observe the site’s features with greater precision and accuracy. We previously knew that Chak’an Itza settlements rested upon an ancient city; however; we had no idea that the city had an urban grid. Like modern cities, Nixtun-Ch’ich’ has crossing streets forming city blocks. No other Maya city is known to have a city grid. This grid was built between 400 and 200 BCE at the time that state level political organization was forming in the Maya area. The ancient grid shaped much later Chak’an Itza community patterns as they built their homes and ceremonial buildings along the edges of the gridded roads.

Our excavations involved test units and horizontal excavations. Test units are small excavations ideally excavated until they encounter bedrock (Figure 4). They document the chronology of the site. We excavated 60 test units to search for occupations dating to between AD 1100 and 1750. We found that the entire site included residences dated to this site period, but the main part of the community—including its political center—stood in the southwest corner of the site. Thus, we concentrated our horizontal excavations in this area. Horizontal excavations expose large areas to uncover buried architecture.  We conduct eight large horizontal excavations in the southwest corner of the site focused on an area referred to as Sector QQ. We also excavated several horizontal excavations in other parts of the site.
